segment.source: WinPE: Storage Area Network (SAN) Policy
segment.target: WinPE: Storage Area Network (SAN) Policy

segment.source: WinPE: Storage Area Network (SAN) Policy
segment.target: WinPE: Storage Area Network (SAN) Policy

segment.source: WinPE: Storage Area Network (SAN) Policy
segment.target: WinPE: Storage Area Network (SAN) Policy

segment.source: Storage area network (SAN) functionality enables a computer to mount disks and other storage devices automatically from other computers.
segment.target: Storage area network (SAN) functionality enables a computer to mount disks and other storage devices automatically from other computers.

segment.source: By configuring the SAN policy on a Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) image, you can control whether or not disks are automatically mounted and which disks can be mounted.
segment.target: By configuring the SAN policy on a Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) image, you can control whether or not disks are automatically mounted and which disks can be mounted.

segment.source: You can also disable the policy to automatically mount disks.
segment.target: You can also disable the policy to automatically mount disks.

segment.source: Configuring the SAN policy on a Windows PE image
segment.target: Configuring the SAN policy on a Windows PE image

segment.source: For Windows PE images that are available in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK), the default SAN policy is to mount available disks automatically.
segment.target: For Windows PE images that are available in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK), the default SAN policy is to mount available disks automatically.

segment.source: But if the SAN environment has many available disks, automatically mounting them might reduce the performance of Windows PE.
segment.target: But if the SAN environment has many available disks, automatically mounting them might reduce the performance of Windows PE.

segment.source: The container ID determines the external and internal disk status.
segment.target: The container ID determines the external and internal disk status.

segment.source: If the device container ID of a disk is the same as the root container ID, the disk is internal.
segment.target: If the device container ID of a disk is the same as the root container ID, the disk is internal.

segment.source: Otherwise, it's an external disk.
segment.target: Otherwise, it's an external disk.

segment.source: You can use the Setsanpolicy.cmd file in the Windows PE tools path to configure the SAN policy on a Windows PE image.
segment.target: You can use the Setsanpolicy.cmd file in the Windows PE tools path to configure the SAN policy on a Windows PE image.

segment.source: To configure the SAN policy on a Windows PE image
segment.target: To configure the SAN policy on a Windows PE image

segment.source: Mount the Windows PE image to an available mount point.
segment.target: Mount the Windows PE image to an available mount point.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: where imageindex is the number of the selected image in the .wim file.
segment.target: where imageindex is the number of the selected image in the .wim file.

segment.source: Run the setsanpolicy command.
segment.target: Run the setsanpolicy command.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: where imagepath is the path of a mounted Windows PE image, and policynumber is the SAN policy number.
segment.target: where imagepath is the path of a mounted Windows PE image, and policynumber is the SAN policy number.

segment.source: These values are valid policynumber values:
segment.target: These values are valid policynumber values:

segment.source: SAN policy number
segment.target: SAN policy number

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Mounts all available storage devices.
segment.target: Mounts all available storage devices.

segment.source: This is the default value.
segment.target: This is the default value.

segment.source: Mounts all storage devices except those on a shared bus.
segment.target: Mounts all storage devices except those on a shared bus.

segment.source: Doesn't mount storage devices.
segment.target: Doesn't mount storage devices.

segment.source: New for Windows 8.
segment.target: New for Windows 8.

segment.source: Makes internal disks offline.
segment.target: Makes internal disks offline.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: All external disks and the boot disk are online.
segment.target: All external disks and the boot disk are online.

segment.source: This example shows how to configure the SAN policy on a Windows PE image to mount all disks except those disks on a shared bus:
segment.target: This example shows how to configure the SAN policy on a Windows PE image to mount all disks except those disks on a shared bus:

segment.source: where 2 is the SAN policy number that mounts all storage device except those on a shared bus.
segment.target: where 2 is the SAN policy number that mounts all storage device except those on a shared bus.

segment.source: Unmount the image and commit the changes.
segment.target: Unmount the image and commit the changes.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Configuring the SAN Policy on a Windows Image
segment.target: Configuring the SAN Policy on a Windows Image

segment.source: You can change the default SAN policy of a Windows image by using Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM) to customize the Microsoft-Windows-PartitionManager component.
segment.target: You can change the default SAN policy of a Windows image by using Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM) to customize the Microsoft-Windows-PartitionManager component.

segment.source: You use the setting to configure the Windows image during an unattended installation.
segment.target: You use the setting to configure the Windows image during an unattended installation.

segment.source: To configure the SAN policy by using an answer file
segment.target: To configure the SAN policy by using an answer file

segment.source: On your technician computer, open Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).
segment.target: On your technician computer, open Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).

segment.source: Click Start, type Windows System Image Manager, and then select Windows System Image Manager.
segment.target: Click Start, type Windows System Image Manager, and then select Windows System Image Manager.

segment.source: Create a new answer file, or update an existing answer file.
segment.target: Create a new answer file, or update an existing answer file.

segment.source: For more information, see Create or Open an Answer File and Best Practices for Authoring Answer Files.
segment.target: For more information, see Create or Open an Answer File and Best Practices for Authoring Answer Files.

segment.source: On the Insert menu, click RunSynchronous.
segment.target: On the Insert menu, click RunSynchronous.

segment.source: Select the configuration pass where you want to install the command.
segment.target: Select the configuration pass where you want to install the command.

segment.source: This can be the auditUser or oobeSystem configuration pass.
segment.target: This can be the auditUser or oobeSystem configuration pass.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Don't use the RunSynchronousNetsh advfirewall command during the specialize configuration pass.
segment.target: Don't use the RunSynchronousNetsh advfirewall command during the specialize configuration pass.

segment.source: The Create Synchronous Command dialog box appears.
segment.target: The Create Synchronous Command dialog box appears.

segment.source: Enter the Netsh advfirewall firewall commands to add them to the answer file, and then click OK.
segment.target: Enter the Netsh advfirewall firewall commands to add them to the answer file, and then click OK.

segment.source: For more information, see the Network Shell (Netsh) Technical Reference.
segment.target: For more information, see the Network Shell (Netsh) Technical Reference.

segment.source: You can convert Netsh commands to Windows PowerShell® commands.
segment.target: You can convert Netsh commands to Windows PowerShell® commands.

segment.source: For more information, see the Netshell to Powershell Conversion Guide.
segment.target: For more information, see the Netshell to Powershell Conversion Guide.

segment.source: In the SynchronousCommand Properties pane, in the Settings section next to Description, enter a description like Enable Windows Messenger.
segment.target: In the SynchronousCommand Properties pane, in the Settings section next to Description, enter a description like Enable Windows Messenger.
